Folder 3. Cistus marifolius Linne√©; Cistus anglicus [TA] Huds.; Cistus hirsutus Huds. [G1]. i. *Helianthemum alpinum folio Pilosellae minoris Fuchsii. Ray. syn. 342. called by Hudson Cistus Hirsutus, & by Linnaeus in the 13th Edit: of Syst. Nat. p. 414, Cistus anglicus, but in all Probability does not differ from the C. marifolius Lin: I gathered it at Gloddaeth near Conway in Carnarnonshire. June [JL].

ii. "Cistus caulibus duris, procumbensibus, foliis ellipticus, hirsutis, inferne tomentosis, petiolis confertis, unifloris, calycibus tomentosis Haller Helv: Vol: 2. p.4. No. 1035. which he makes to be the Cistus marifolius Lin: Sp. 741. suffruticosus exstipulatus, foliis oppositis oblongis petiolatis planis | subtus incarnis. Flores exigui flavi. Folia ad serram conferta. Burrel: fig: 366. aggres best, w? Lin: places under his Var. B of Cistus canus. Hudson's Cistus hirsutus, is now made by Lin: Cistus anglicus. Lin: Mantiss: p. 241, but probably without Reason or by Mistake, as he says of it Folia utrinque; viridia, & floraes racemosi albi. But neither Leaves nor flowers are so in this. I therefore conclude it to be the C. marifolius. Lin: sp. 741. not the C. canus because the leaves are not obovate, tho' these two are very much alike. Ayton [William Aiton] always receiv'd this kind from abroad for C. marifolius" [JL].
iii. *C. canus Scopoli: No. 647 agrees well with this. He suspects C. marifolius w* has Leaves like this, & his alpestris to be all varieties of the same species [JL].
iv. "C. canus Lin: or a var: of it as I believe. An English species called C. hirsutus by Huds." [JL].

Folder 1. Euphorbia exigua [G]. "T found this plant, 1773, in our Cornfields, and supposed it to be only a variety of the exigua. I am still of the same opinion. It agrees indeed pretty well with the Tishymalus Segetum longifolius. Cat. Cant. App & Raii Syn. p.312, since it is there described as Esulae exiguae Tragi persimilis, sed major; the last circumstance may easily be accounted for; because of the Umbella quinquefida in the one & trifida in the other. The Segetalis in Ray and the Segetalis in Linnaeus are certainly two very different Plants; and I should be glad to know, and I wish it may be in your power to inform me, whether those Specimens, w?* Mr. Lyons found near Triplow, be at all different from this Specimen-another circumstance also makes me conclude that it is only a variety of the exigua; because found in company w'^ it, and am inclined to think that it never will be found anywhere else. I gathered more of it at the same Time; but have either mislaid or shuffled it away. But if I should find the same variety again, I will endeavour to collect the Seed of it, and try what it will do in my Garden. *Supposing all other circumstances equal, the quinquefida must be to the trifida in Magnitude in the Proportion of 5 to 3, w? wants only one third part of being twice as big" [B].

"Arundo Epigeios. It was found in a green Lane or Road leading from Stoke-Newington to Southgate near London by Mr. Alchorne. The Specimen he gathered there differ'd very little from the A: Calamagrostis. The Spike is much thinner set with Flowers, or more lax, the Glumes were reddish at the Points, greenish towards the Base, & hardly so much pointed as in the A: Calamagrostis. No difference was observable between the Stalks & Leaves, except in being somewhat smaller than in the A: Calamagr: as if a weaker Plant only. The same was brought from Sweden by D* Solander & given to M* Alchorne. These Samples were uniform in their Colour, being of a yellowish brown or frillmort Colour, as if decay'd or ill'ary'd. They were otherwise like M' Alchorne's English Specimen in all Respects. These Specimens corresponded with those in Budley's Hortus siccus in the British Museum examin'd & compar'd by M* Alchorne. Memorandum. That I search among my Specimens, & see if I have not got this very kind" [JL]. 
 ii. "This is the true Arundo Epigeios Lin: as appear'd by comparing it with Alchorne's Specimen which agreed with those in Budley's Hortus siccus. I [on reverse:] believe I gather'd it in Windsor Forest near the Duke's Lodge going towards Virginia Water in a Boggy Place to the left of the true Road from Windsor" [JL].

1 folder. Aira setacea Hud. [TA]. "Aira Setacea Huds. Aira foliis setaceis, panicula secunda, ramosa, nutante, aristis flosculis duplo longioribus, recurvis. This is certainly the plant intended by Huds. but very badly described both as to Habit & Place of Growth. I found it on Cawston Decoy, 12 Miles North of Norwich, in a very deep rotten Soil. Its Leaves were Scarce visible, being intirely immersed in Water. Our Idea of the Aira setacea Huds. was that it must be a very small Plant, growing on a very dry barren Soil; for such is the nature of Stratton Heath in general. There are indeed some rotton boggy places also upon it, of the same nature with Cawston Decoy; but we should never have thought of searching for it, unless we have been particularly directed to do so. I make no doubt but this Plant may now be found, not only on Stratton Heath; but in many other Parts of the Kingdom, by those who are qualified to look after it and have hardiness enough to tread the Bogs in proper Season. [on reverse] Collected all that I found of it, were only nine Specimens, two of which Catalo want the Bottom leaves, they being intirely out of my reach. I have sent you four compleat ones, and beg you would give one of them to M' Banks." [B]; "Rev Mr Bryant" [JL] [four specimens are present, so it appears that Lightfoot did not pass one on to Joseph Banks as Bryant requested]. "Aira Setacea, Huds.
